references: To simulate a federated environment, we use the Flower frameworkÂ (Beutel etÂ al., 2020) and utilize FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) as the optimization algorithm to construct the global model from clientsâ€™ local updates. Additionally, a number of primary parameters, listed in TableÂ 1b, were selected to control the federated setting in our experiments. In allÂ FedLNÂ experiments, where noise level estimation is computed based on a modelâ€™s confidence, we use a fixed scoring threshold percentile Î½ğœˆ\nu to 75%percent7575\%, while for embedding-based noise discovery the neighborhood size in kNN to 100100100, which we found to be working well during our initial exploration. Further, we set the clientsâ€™ participation rate in each federated round (qğ‘q) to be equal to 808080%. It is important to note that we employ uniform random sampling for the clientsâ€™ selection strategy, as other approaches for adequate clients election are outside the scope of our work.

For the data distribution process in our federated experiments, we randomly partitioned the datasets across the available clients in a non-overlapping fashion, controlling the amount of data across clients through parameter Ïƒğœ\sigma. With Ïƒğœ\sigma set to 252525% and a random partitioning of data among clients, the resulting data distribution across clients is intentionally imbalanced. This type of data distribution is common across clientsâ€™ data in federated settingÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021), where the variation in the number of samples per client is influenced by the characteristics of the respective users. To generate label noise in the datasets, we constructed a noise matrix Qyâˆ£yâˆ—subscriptğ‘„conditionalğ‘¦superscriptğ‘¦Q_{y{\mid}y^{*}} based on parameters nlsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘™n_{l} and nssubscriptğ‘›ğ‘ n_{s}, similar toÂ (Northcutt etÂ al., 2019). While in centralized settings a single noise matrix was considered, in FL we constructed a unique noise matrix per client, thus introducing distinct noise profiles across clients. We note that the noise injection process has been performed after the data partioning process. With parameter Fğ¹F, we controlled the number of â€œnoisyâ€ clients, i.e., clientsâ€™ holding noisy labeled instances in their datasets. Lastly, for an accurate comparison between our experiments, we manage any randomness during data partitioning, label noise injection and training procedures by using a seed alongside the parameters as presented in TableÂ 1.

Considered approaches include Confidence Learning (CL)Â (Northcutt etÂ al., 2019), FedCorrÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2022), while Softmax and EnergyÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2020) correspond to our model confidence approach, when the corresponding scoring function is used. Embeddings account for the proposed embedding-based discovery of noisy labels during the initialization phase of FL. Federated parameters are set to Mğ‘€M=30, Fğ¹F=80%, Ïƒğœ\sigma=25%,
while Rğ‘…R, Eğ¸E and qğ‘q are fixed to 150,5,1 and 30,1,80 for FedCorr and all other approaches, respectively.

references: In TableÂ 2, the AUC scores of all considered approaches is reported for CIFAR-10 and SpeechCommands. Comparing all model-based approaches with embedding-based one, we note that the latterâ€™s performance is superior. This is due to the difference in the quality of the noise-free â€œsourceâ€ that is utilized to detect noisy labeled instances on the proposed methods. While embeddings are extracted from a pre-trained model that is completely unrelated to clientsâ€™ own models or their label noise, the remaining approaches rely on the â€œmemorization effectâ€ of deep learning models during the early stages to detect noisy instances. Consequently, as the label noise increases in the federated setting, a certain degree of noise will be implicitly introduced during the model aggregation process. This can be observed by the sharp decrease, averaging 7%, in the AUC score for detecting noisy labeled instances across the two datasets in all model-based approaches when the label noise level (nlsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘™n_{l}) is increased from 40% to 70%. However, even in the presence of high levels of label noise, it is still possible to observe significant differences in the generalization capabilities of client models with noisy labels and those with clean labels. This information is valuable for re-weighting the contribution of client models during server-side model aggregation. To illustrate this point, we present histograms of energy scores obtained at Rğ‘…R=303030 in FigureÂ 6, showing a clear separation between the scores of â€œcleanâ€ and â€œnoisyâ€ clients. Here, we consider two cases of label noise: one with clients sharing the same amount of noise and another with a random label noise distribution, both maintaining the same number of noisy labeled instances.

On the contrary, the embedding-based discovery approach exhibits greater robustness to the clientâ€™s noise profile. However, there is an exception in the case of high noise with high sparsity (where nlsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘™n_{l}=707070% and nssubscriptğ‘›ğ‘ n_{s}=707070/100100100%). In this scenario, labels belonging to groups of classes become easily confused. TableÂ 2 shows that, on average, there is an approximate 30% decline in the AUC score when nlsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘™n_{l}=707070% and nssubscriptğ‘›ğ‘ n_{s} increases from 404040% to 707070%. While the computed embeddings are unrelated to the noise profile, they amplify the noise level through faulty label estimation. To understand this behavior, we provide an intuition behind how noisy labeled instances are identified using our embedding-based approach in FigureÂ 7, where t-SNE visualization is used for CIFAR-10 embeddings extracted usingÂ (Radford etÂ al., 2021). Noisy labeled instances are indicated by black circles in FigureÂ 7(a). As discussed in SectionÂ 4.3.1, the discovery of noisy labels using the â€œNNCâ€ method relies on the detection of outliers in a given neighborhood through majority vote, as shown in FigureÂ 7(b). However, in cases of high noise sparsity, labels from a group of classes become mixed, resulting in a concentration of noisy labels from a particular class in a given neighborhood. This amplifies the noise level and leads to incorrect label estimation. For example, in the neighborhood of a catâ€™s image (ground truth label) in the embedding space, where 7 out of the 10 samples are mislabeled as dogs due to high noise sparsity between cats and dogs, â€œNNCâ€ computes the estimated label based on the dominant label in the neighborhood, resulting in a dogâ€™s label being assigned. To overcome this issue, the â€œAKDâ€ method (see SectionÂ 4.3.2) can be used to exploit embeddings for distillation rather than fixing labels directly, as demonstrated in SectionÂ 5.3.2.

We include FedCorrÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2022) on all vision-based datasets, while CL corresponds to the Confidence LearningÂ (Northcutt etÂ al., 2019) technique. The accuracies for AKD with globally aggregated modelâ€™s outputs (i.e., logits) as supervisory signals are provided in TableÂ 7 of the Appendix. Federated parameters are set to Rğ‘…R=200, Mğ‘€M=30, Fğ¹F=80%, Eğ¸E=1, qğ‘q=80%, and Ïƒğœ\sigma=25%.

references: Here, we compareÂ FedLNÂ to determine the achieved improvements versus other considered baselines, and assessÂ FedLNÂ effectiveness on a wide range of tasks from both vision and audio domains. To this end, we perform experiments on all datasets for a diverse number of noisy profiles, varying both noise level (nlsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘™n_{l}) and sparsity (nssubscriptğ‘›ğ‘ n_{s}). For a fair comparison, we utilize identical data partitioning and noisy injection schemes in all related experiments. TableÂ 3 provides the accuracy scores on test sets averaged across three independent runs to be robust against differences in randomness involve in training deep neural networks. In the experiments we conducted in centralized setting, models are trained until convergence to obtain the resulting accuracy on a test set, which is presented in the centralized rows of TableÂ 3. Additionally, for ease of comparison and benchmarking, we include the obtained accuracy for all considered approaches and datasets when no additional noise in injected in data, thus, acting as an upper bound of modelsâ€™ performance. In the case of AKD, we report the performance for the case of embeddings as source of supervision in TableÂ 3, while the accuracies for identical experiments performed for AKD with globally aggregated modelâ€™s outputs (i.e., logits) as supervisory signal are provided in TableÂ 7 of the Appendix.

In TableÂ 3, we observe our approaches can improve the modelâ€™s performance compared to standard FedAvg across all datasets significantly. Consequently, we can conclude thatÂ FedLNÂ can be applied in a federated environment with noisy labels to boost the performance, independent of the learning task or inputsâ€™ modality. In particular, comparing the rows for nlsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘™n_{l}=707070% we note an increase of 22.6722.6722.67% in accuracy on average usingÂ FedLNÂ across the considered tasks compared to the standard federated model.

From the results presented in TableÂ 4, we note thatÂ FedLNÂ retains high efficacy, even if a different architecture is used. In particular, for nlsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘™n_{l}=707070%, we notice an increase of  5.325.325.32% in accuracy on average usingÂ FedLNÂ compared to the standard â€œFedAvgâ€, with all three of proposed approaches following similar performance gains to the ones observed in TableÂ 3. This indicates that both of our embeddings and model confidence based methods can be employed in FL to mitigate the effect of label noise and improve modelâ€™s generalizability, irrespective of the architecture of federated model to be learned.

We present our findings in TableÂ 5, where we note that the number of noisy clients has a relatively low impact on the ability of NNC to perform the label correction process, as the embeddings remain unaffected by the noise introduced by those clients. On the contrary, when trained with NA-FedAvg, the modelâ€™s performance deteriorates once all clients become noisy (Fğ¹F=100100100%). However, even with as few as 202020% of clients being â€œcleanâ€, the modelâ€™s performance reaches approximately 707070% across all noise profiles, as shown in TableÂ 3. Furthermore, in cases where the label noise is sparse across clients (Fğ¹F=252525%), we observe that NA-FedAvg performance is superior to NNC. Although the overall number of noisy labeled instances has a negligible effect on the FL process, a small amount of label noise is introduced to â€œcleanâ€ clients due to slight imperfections in label estimation via NNC.

We perform experiments on both CIFAR-10/100N datasets utilizingÂ FedLNÂ approaches, and include standard FedAvg with same training configuration, to clearly illustrate performance gain of our approach. For a fair comparison, we included CL and FedCorr performance in identical experiments, as these were the two most prominent approaches from TableÂ 3. While the train set of CIFAR-10/100N was annotated by humans, the original noise-free test set of both datasets is used for evaluation. Furthermore, we randomly distribute the data across clients; thus no clear group of â€œcleanâ€ clients is considered in this case, which make the learning even more challenging. From the CIFAR-10N results presented in FigureÂ 8, we note thatÂ FedLNÂ retains itâ€™s effectiveness, while moving from synthetic to real-world noise patterns. In particular, modelâ€™s recognition rate remains within 222% to the ones reported in TableÂ 3 for nlsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘™n_{l}=404040%. In the case of CIFAR100N, where the complexity of the task is increased due to large number of classes, we train all models for 500500500 federated rounds (Rğ‘…R=500500500). In this case, we observe that embedding-based supervision via AKD outperforms the remaining approaches, validating that AKDâ€™s performance can be especially beneficial if longer federated training is possible. Subsequently, we note thatÂ FedLNÂ is able to largely address the challenges introduced from real-life noise patterns and is able to improve the recognition rate by 999%, compared to the standard FL process. Therefore, our approaches can be useful for everyday users, who utilize FL services and are requested to provide labels for their data, either explicitly or through their own activities (e.g., the next word prediction in GboardÂ (Leroy etÂ al., 2019)), which are inherently noisy.

references: We present our findings in TableÂ 5, where we note that the number of noisy clients has a relatively low impact on the ability of NNC to perform the label correction process, as the embeddings remain unaffected by the noise introduced by those clients. On the contrary, when trained with NA-FedAvg, the modelâ€™s performance deteriorates once all clients become noisy (Fğ¹F=100100100%). However, even with as few as 202020% of clients being â€œcleanâ€, the modelâ€™s performance reaches approximately 707070% across all noise profiles, as shown in TableÂ 3. Furthermore, in cases where the label noise is sparse across clients (Fğ¹F=252525%), we observe that NA-FedAvg performance is superior to NNC. Although the overall number of noisy labeled instances has a negligible effect on the FL process, a small amount of label noise is introduced to â€œcleanâ€ clients due to slight imperfections in label estimation via NNC.

From the results provided in TableÂ 6, it can be observed that the performance of NA-FedAvg starts to deteriorate when label noise is injected into the data of â€œcleanâ€ clients. Specifically, with a noise addition of 0.1Ã—nl0.1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘™0.1\times n_{l}, an average drop in accuracy of 3% is noted across the noise profiles. This drop occurs as NA-FedAvg utilizes â€œcleanâ€ clients models ability to generalize faster to act as a â€œsourceâ€ for detection of noisy labeled instances. This drop occurs as NA-FedAvg relies on the ability of any available â€œcleanâ€ clientâ€™s models to generalize faster, acting as a â€œsourceâ€ for the detection of noisy labeled instances. While the overall label noise present in the FL process is similar to that of the experiments reported in TableÂ 5; here, we introduce label noise to all â€œcleanâ€ clients instead of flipping them to noisy ones. As a result, a clear separation between the energy scores obtained from the two groups of clients, as illustrated in FigureÂ 6, begins to diminish. Consequently, the ability of NA-FedAvg to determine a suitable threshold for determining noisy labelled instances sharply deteriorates, leading to poor generalizability of the obtained model. On the contrary, NNC remains effective in performing label correction and producing more generalizable models, even when nlsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘™n_{l} noise is introduced across all clients in FL. Therefore, NNC can be a preferable approach in cases where strong assumptions are made about the noise profile, such as the absence of clients with quality labels.

references: Here, we compareÂ FedLNÂ to determine the achieved improvements versus other considered baselines, and assessÂ FedLNÂ effectiveness on a wide range of tasks from both vision and audio domains. To this end, we perform experiments on all datasets for a diverse number of noisy profiles, varying both noise level (nlsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘™n_{l}) and sparsity (nssubscriptğ‘›ğ‘ n_{s}). For a fair comparison, we utilize identical data partitioning and noisy injection schemes in all related experiments. TableÂ 3 provides the accuracy scores on test sets averaged across three independent runs to be robust against differences in randomness involve in training deep neural networks. In the experiments we conducted in centralized setting, models are trained until convergence to obtain the resulting accuracy on a test set, which is presented in the centralized rows of TableÂ 3. Additionally, for ease of comparison and benchmarking, we include the obtained accuracy for all considered approaches and datasets when no additional noise in injected in data, thus, acting as an upper bound of modelsâ€™ performance. In the case of AKD, we report the performance for the case of embeddings as source of supervision in TableÂ 3, while the accuracies for identical experiments performed for AKD with globally aggregated modelâ€™s outputs (i.e., logits) as supervisory signal are provided in TableÂ 7 of the Appendix.
